author: Richard Barley
title: Winning Trade Turns Money Loser
text:
Corporate bonds have been the easiest way to eke out a higher gain in a yield-starved world. This year, though, they are doing the opposite. The corporate bond moneymaker has gone into reverse.
U.S. investment-grade corporate bonds—issued by blue-chip names with relatively strong balance sheets—have returned minus 2.6% this year, compared with minus 1.7% for Treasurys, ICE BofAML indexes show. The poor performance is due to widening credit spreads, with the gap between corporate bond yields and underlying government yields...
